Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Congress of the Americas, Montreal, Canada, July 24-28, 2017: Administration of Travel Grants for US Participants
Award.AbstractNarration:
To support US participation in the international Mathematical Congress of the Americas, which runs July 24-28, 2017 in Montreal, Canada, the American Mathematical Society is administering a travel grant program for US-based mathematical scientists. Initiated in 2013, the MCA is a quadrennial gathering administered by the Mathematical Council of the Americas, a network of over twenty societies (including the AMS), institutes, and agencies throughout North, South, and Latin America as well as the Caribbean nations. Like the first, this second congress draws mathematicians from around the Western Hemisphere and the rest of the world and presents an excellent opportunity for exchange of ideas on an international stage in a broad array of mathematical areas. Early career mathematicians, i.e., those having completed a PhD within the last six years, are especially encouraged to apply and will receive priority consideration from the committee reviewing applications. Individuals from groups that are underrepresented in mathematics are strongly encouraged to apply. Full information and the application form are at http://www.ams.org/programs/travel-grants/mca.

The general goal of the 2017 MCA travel grant program is to promote the nation's leadership in mathematical research on the world stage by encouraging and supporting the interactions of mathematicians based in the US with their counterparts throughout the Americas and the rest of the world. By participating, mathematicians will learn of the latest developments and current work around the Western Hemisphere and also contribute to the increasingly-global endeavor of mathematical research. With a focus on supporting early-career mathematicians, this travel grant program is an investment in the future of the US's continuing leadership in this arena. Anticipating approximately 1,500 attendees from around the Western Hemisphere and the rest of the world, the organizers have included five plenary and twenty semi-plenary speakers, mostly from the Americas, on the program. The program also includes seventy-two special sessions devoted to such topics as algebraic structures, complex variables, group theory, model theory, combinatorics, symbolic dynamics, cryptography, finite fields, operator theory, applications to condensed matter, probability theory, computational science, optimization and control, arithmetic geometry, harmonic analysis, celestial mechanics, gauge theory, nonlinear partial differential equations, fractal geometry, cohomology, fluid dynamics, inverse problems, and number theory. The MCA is also the occasion for presenting the MCA Prize, the Americas Prize, and the Solomon Lefschetz Medals, all awards that recognize the distinctive achievement and broad impact of the recipients' research or professional activities. A complete list of all special sessions is on the MCA web site, https://mca2017.org/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project was a grants program administered by the American Mathematical Society (AMS) to support travel by approximately fifty US-based mathematicians to the Mathematical Congress of the Americas (MCA), held in Montreal, Canada, July 24 - 28, 2017 (https://mca2017.org/). The travel-grant program's overarching goal was to foster US participation in mathematical research and international exchange of ideas, collaboration, and cooperation. Mathematicians at all levels of experience past the completion of a PhD were eligible to apply for the program, and those at an early career stage--no more than six years past the doctorate--were given priority in the selection process.

The AMS received 137 applications, and a panel of eight reviewers evaluated them based on mathematical merit, potential for benefit from and contribution to the Congress, and career stage. Awards of up to $1,350 were ultimately made to forty-nine individuals who traveled to the Congress. These individuals came from nineteen states, women comprised almost forty percent, and approximately two-thirds were early career.

The program provided many opportunities for the awardees to collaborate, present research work, receive feedback, make significant progress on research problems, and forge connections across borders. At the time they submitted their travel vouchers, grant recipients were asked to complete a brief narrative questionnaire about their experience in Montreal, and most responded. Their responses were overwhelmingly positive about the experience at the Congress, and especially those who had not been to an international meeting were excited to meet and talk with their counterparts from around the Americas--especially those in Brazil, Canada, and Mexico. A couple of excerpts are indicative: "A long-standing collaboration was brought to publication-ready status ... We also spent time discussing another project ... which we hope to have ready for publication in 2018," and "The [grant] could not have come at a more crucial time for me since I am nearing the end of my post-doctoral stage ... Having the support provided by the AMS [and NSF] to come to the conference played a huge role in my attending it. Indeed, without the funding, I would not have gone to the meeting."

Started in 2013, the MCA is a conference held every four years under the aegis of the Mathematical Council of the Americas (http://www.mcofamericas.org/), an organization consisting of thirty-two professional societies, associations, and institutes in North, Central, and South America. The stated goal of the Congress is "to internationally highlight the excellence of mathematical achievement in the Americas and foster collaboration among researchers, students, institutions, and mathematical societies in the Americas."  MCA 2017 drew approximately 1,100 registrants, principally from the Americas but several from around the globe. Some 380 traveled from the US, 300 from Canada, and 280 from various Latin American countries. The program included 74 special sessions, 20 invited lectures, several awards, and an array of mathematical, cultural, and social activities.
